Suffixes and enclitics occupy a unique place in the Igbo lexicon as important determiners of meaning for many other lexical units.",,,"",echeruo
en,"Briefly, suffixes may be said to modify the general meaning of verbs, while enclitics modify the meaning of sentences and utterances.",,,"",echeruo
en,"Accordingly, the meanings attached to them in the list below must be understood as only indicating a general tendency or direction of meaning.",,,"",echeruo

en,"It is a point of interest to note that the vowels in these suffixes and enclitics are invariably open, the exceptions being in the case of those suffixes which retain the force of verbs, and so take positive imperative inflexions.",,,"",echeruo
en,"In standard written Igbo, these suffixes and enclitics are written together with the verbs they modify, without the hyphen.",,,"",echeruo
en,sö-ba = söba) are strictly for the convenience of the reader only.,,,"",echeruo

ig,﻿A,alph,H," 'First letter of the Igbo: en,"J whatever - ihe omela = whatever haloes: ihc okwula = whatever lie says: ihc t""> hi'ilti — whatever it is, var.",,,"",echeruo
en,-li sfx [H] able to: can - 0 ga-emeli'.,,,"",echeruo
en,' Is he able to (do it)'.,,,"",echeruo
en,-lie sfx [HH] have the ability or capacity to do something- delic= able to writev hulie= able to cany.,,,"",echeruo
en,-lie sfx [HH] used to indicate upward movement - gbalie = kick upwards: welie = take up (and stow away).,,,"",echeruo
en,-lie sfx [LH] used with other verbs to indicate that the desired action was more than exceeded or was carried too far - gbulie = cut up in bits.,,,"",echeruo
en,-na sfx [L] whatever - ihe otnena = whatever haloes: iheokwana= whatever he says: ihe ö hiina = whatever it is.,,,"",echeruo
en,-nöö sfx [HH] used to mark special emphasis on the action of the verb.,,,"",echeruo
en,"-nü sfx [H] an enclitic attached to a main verb to indicate an intensification of the action of the main verb: the equivalent of the auxiliary ""do"" in Engl ish - meenii = go.",,,"",echeruo
en,"do it: hïakwanü = make sure you all come: do, come.",,,"",echeruo
en,"-nwa sfx [L] emphatic marker for a pronoun - niiinwa = / myself: yanwu = he himself, ününwa = you yourselves.",,,"",echeruo
en,-nwöö sfx [HH] (öni'ca) used to mark special emphasis on the action of the verb - ka ödïmvñö - as it is: as things now stand.,,,"",echeruo
en,-pü sfx [L] used to indicate separation as a result of the action of the verb to which it is attached - cüpü = drive out: expel.,,,"",echeruo
en,"-rie sfx [LH] used with other verbs to indicate that the action was more than exceeded or was earned too far - gburie = cut into many

en,"-ri'CO sfx [HH(H)] logical opposite of ""-fü"": marks fully actualised actions: event in the ""already "" category - O gwülarïï= it's been long since finished: o mecaalañï = he has long since completed [the taskj.",,,"",echeruo
en,"-ta sfx [H] bring an action to Completion: complete action of main verb - züta = purchase: complete purchase, var -te.",,,"",echeruo
en,-ta sfx [L] do something well - inüta = learn well: sala = answer well.,,,"",echeruo
en,-te sfx [H] bringing an action to completion.,,,"",echeruo
en,to complete action of main verb - bute = successfully carry off var.,,,"",echeruo
en,-te sfx [L] do something well - mete= do well: kwete — sing well.,,,"",echeruo
en,-tuo sfx [LH] used to indicate movement out of or down from (e.,,,"",echeruo
en,perch or station) -gbatuo = shoot down: hu-tuo = canv down from (e.,,,"",echeruo
en,shelf): wetuo = take out (as an exception).,,,"",echeruo
en,"-tii sfx [H] signals action only a bit of which has been completed - metüiinetüwa = start doing: begin doing a little bit of [some action j
-wa sfx [L] (Owei'c) begin: continue doing-rüwa =-hegin doing, var.",,,"",echeruo
en,-wanye sfx [HH] used to indicate further continuation of the action of preceding verb - bawunye = get even richer: jiiwanve = get even uglier.,,,"",echeruo
en,or a negative performance -omerözï = it did not happen afterall: he did not perform afterall.,,,"",echeruo
Traditional Igbo numeration went in multiples oltwcnly.",,,"",echeruo
en,system has been modernised through decimalisation.,,,"",echeruo
en,"This was effected principally by a) the elimination of the numbers 20 (-- ögii-ohu) and 400 (= nnü) and b) the adoption of four numbers: narï (= 100), puku (- 1.",,,"",echeruo
en,These numbers are combined witli the numbers 1 to 10 to form tbe new numerals.,,,"",echeruo
en,Na is used as the connector in all additions.,,,"",echeruo
en,"Tn certain complex numbers, this can lead to ambiguity, especially when the use of na obscures the hierarchy of operations.",,,"",echeruo
en,"Rule 1: The following numerals define the numeral system:
Numbers derived from simple additions are formed with the conjunction ""na"" before the
Numbers that are multiples of these cardinal numerals are formed by placing the multiplier
number(s) directly after the cardinal number, as for example:
en,"multiples and additions) are represented in units
corresponding to bracketed components of the numbers in the addition.",,,"",echeruo
smalles number comes last within each set of multiples and additions.",,,"",echeruo
puku narï asaa na narï asaa na in na asaa = 700,000+(700+( 10+7))     =700,717
nde asaa na puku asaa na iri asaa na asaa = 7,000.",,,"",echeruo
en,"000+(700+(70+7))   = 7,700,077 Note that, to eliminate some of the resulting ambiguity, the word, tikwasï or tükwasï (= ""plus"" or ""add"") may replace na (= ""and"").",,,"",echeruo

The list below, produced by leading members of the SPILC, is a selection of terms recently introduced to meet the needsof the language especially in the field of linguistics and literature.",,,"",echeruo

en,"Working in collaboration with, or under the auspices of the Nigerian Educational Research and Development Council, researchers have developed new coinages (for Igbo and the other' national' languages) covering other aspects of national life, most especially, in the areas of politics and public administration.",,,"",echeruo
en,"As may be expected, some of the new coinages have not been well received by the general public, and their use has been largely limited to the work of those who coined them.",,,"",echeruo

en,"There is considerable skepticism about the true value of these forced attempts to invent words for terms which, indeed, have no fixed meanings in the European languages from which they are derived.",,,"",echeruo
en,"For this reason, although many of these ""inkhorn terms"", as they could with much justification be called, are ingeniously devised, they do not yet belong in the general lexicon.",,,"",echeruo
en,"For more information on these terms, see the Bibliography.",,,"",echeruo
